newsArray.title: IND vs. AFG 2nd T20I in Indore: Police detain pitch invader for caressing and hugging Virat Kohli‚Äôs feet
creator: CricketCountry Staff
newsArray.description: A young man was taken into custody after he got past security to hug Virat Kohli during the India vs. Afghanistan T20 International at Holkar Stadium in Indore. The post IND vs. AFG 2nd T20I in Indore: Police detain pitch invader for caressing and hugging Virat Kohli‚Äôs feet appeared first on Cricket Country.
newsArray.content: In the second T20 International, India easily defeated Afghanistan by six wickets, securing a series victory in Indore on Sunday. On a calm pitch at the Holkar Stadium, Afghanistan was bowled out for 172 by Axar Patel, leading the bowling attack. Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shivam Dube then made quick work of half-centuries to help India win with 26 balls remaining. Virat Kohli, the former captain of India, made his T20I cricket debut in this match. Since November 2022, when India faced England in the semi-final of the 2022 T20 World Cup, Kohli has not participated in an international match in the format. while could be expected, the Indore crowd screamed Kohli‚Äôs name a lot during the game, even while he sat in the bench following his dismissal during India‚Äôs chase. During the Afghanistan innings, there was also a minor interruption as a spectator made their way to the ground and collided with Kohli. He hugged Kohli and put his hands on his feet before lifting him off the ground. Police detained the young man and brought him to the Tukoganj police station. According to a police officer, the young person entered the Holkar Stadium through Narendra Hirwani Gate with a match ticket. According to him, the young man appeared to be a huge fan of Kohli and went inside the stadium by scaling the railing of the press box in an attempt to meet the player. The young person was being questioned, the officer said. The official stated that further actions in the matter will be made based on the interrogation. A man in Indore says he was a pitch invader. In the midst of it all, a supporter on the social media site X (previously Twitter) asserted that they were the ones that went past security to give Kohli a hug. The biggest accomplishment of Aarav‚Äôs life, according to him, is having a display photo of Kohli in his profile and using the handle @sigma__male_. During the chase, instead of acting as an anchor like he usually does, Kohli came out running. The 35-year-old scored 29 runs off of 16 balls before getting out in the final powerplay over. Subsequently, Jaiswal and Dube mercilessly battered the bowlers from Afghanistan into submission. Yashasvi was dismissed after smashing 68 off 34 balls, including six sixes, but Dube finished unbeaten with a 32-ball 63 that included four maximums. Jaiswal scored his second consecutive undefeated half-century in this series while hitting six sixes in his innings. The latter, who was undefeated at 60 off 40 balls, had also guided India to victory in the opening game. India‚Äôs chase got off to a rough start as Fazalhaq Farooqi (1-28) knocked out skipper Rohit Sharma for a golden duck. However, Jaiswal, 22, and Virat Kohli, 29, forged a 57-run partnership that put India ahead. When Dube and Jaiswal teamed up for a third-wicket partnership, they quickly put on 92 runs in the next seven overs. When India lost two quick wickets to Karim Janat (2-13), including Jaiswal, the momentum had not changed much.

newsArray.description: The visuals of the daring fan hugging Virat Kohli spread like wildfire on social media platforms, capturing the surreal moment when the fan, undeterred by security, embraced the cricketing icon. Reported by Zee News 22 minutes ago.
newsArray.content: Monday, 15 January 2024 ( 55 minutes ago ) The visuals of the daring fan hugging Virat Kohli spread like wildfire on social media platforms, capturing the surreal moment when the fan, undeterred by security, embraced the cricketing icon. üëì View full article

newsArray.title: Sealy leads U19s to warm-up win against NZ
newsArray.description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match...
newsArray.content: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match yesterday in South Africa. The Barbadian left-arm spinner bagged four for 21 from nine overs and five other bowlers took one wicket apiece. The Caribbean side dismissed the New Zealanders for 131 in 39.2 overs in the match at the Braam Fisherville Sports Complex. Two of Sealy‚Äôs victims were trapped leg before wicket and another was bowled, to signify the accuracy of his spell, after West Indies won the toss and decided to field. Fellow Barbadian Joshua Dorne, not out on 45, and Antiguan Jewel Andrew, not out on 36, then led the run chase for West Indies. They shared an unbroken stand of 58 for the fifth wicket to get the Caribbean side over the finish line with 25.1 overs remaining, after they stumbled to 74 for four in the 17th over. The match is the first of two for the side, led by Stephan Pascal, ahead of their opening match in the World Cup against hosts South Africa on Friday at the J.B. Marks Oval in Potchefstroom. They face Nepal tomorrow at the St Stithians Main Oval in another warm-up game. West Indies never let New Zealand off the hook, taking wickets at regular intervals throughout the innings, and they reduced the Young Black Caps to 75 for five. Tom Jones led the way with 24 for New Zealand and Lachlan Stackpole got 23, but no other batsmen passed 20. West Indies were 19 for two inside the first five overs. New Zealand pace bowling captain Oscar Jackson took two for 14 from three overs and had them wobbling further before they reached the halfway stage. Dorne, batting at three, held the innings together with some composed batting and carried them the rest of the way in a stable partnership with Andrew. For their first-round matches ‚Äì all to be played at the J.B. Marks Oval ‚Äì West Indies have been drawn alongside the South Africans, Scotland, and England in Group B in the World Cup. They face the Scots on January 24 and the English two days later. The top three sides from each first round group will progress to the Super Six stage to be played from January 30 to February 3. The semi-finals, on February 6 and 8, and the final, on February 11, will all be played at Willowmore Park in Benoni.

newsArray.title: WI hope to rebuild reputation Down Under, says Da Silva
newsArray.description: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five...
newsArray.content: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five players in the 15-member Test squad of the Caribbean side that has returned Down Under for the series that opens on Wednesday at the Adelaide Oval before moving to the Gabba in Brisbane on January 25. West Indies were beaten convincingly in two Tests in late 2022 in Australia, and with several established players making themselves unavailable, including former captain Jason Holder and fellow all-rounder Kyle Mayers, because of Twenty20 franchise playing commitments, the Test squad includes seven uncapped players. At least three of the uncapped players are likely to make their debuts during the first Test, but Da Silva, who requires only two dismissals to reach 100 in the format, said the squad was keen to prove the doubters wrong. ‚ÄúLast year is last year, and we‚Äôre here to try again,‚Äù he told reporters yesterday when West Indies stepped up preparations for the Frank Worrell Trophy series with a training session at the iconic match venue. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to give it our best effort. We have a few new faces, so there‚Äôs going to be a bit of new blood coming in. I know the boys are excited, and I‚Äôm definitely excited and raring to go. ‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs really keen. Seven uncapped players. If they haven‚Äôt gotten a taste, they‚Äôre really raring to go get a taste of it, so the mood in the camp is great, and we‚Äôre really looking forward to it.‚Äù West Indies have not beaten the Australians in a Test series at home or abroad in a little more than 31 years, and they have gone 19 matches in close to 21 years without winning a Test against the Baggy Greens, but Da Silva said the series is a chance for them to start rebuilding their fading Test reputation. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs always the goal,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEach and every one of us here is looking forward to making the West Indies a winning team again. That‚Äôs the main goal we have. ‚ÄúWe talk about it every day, about getting back to those days, but it‚Äôs a new era now, and we‚Äôre just looking forward to making our own brand and playing that brand of cricket.‚Äù Former West Indies captain and batting maestro Brian Lara will spend the two Tests behind the TV commentary microphone for Fox Cricket, but he attended the training session to share some of his knowledge with the players in his role of mentor, which he assumed last February. ‚ÄúThe knowledge he has is second to none,‚Äù Da Silva said about working with his fellow Trinidadian, who holds the world records for highest individual Test and first-class scores of 400 not out and 501 not out, respectively. ‚ÄúWhat he‚Äôs done for the game, what he‚Äôs done for West Indies cricket on his own, just having him around, just his presence alone speaks for itself. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs here to work with everyone, he‚Äôs our mentor, so he‚Äôs going to be helping everybody, bowlers and batters because he has so much experience, I think everybody can learn from him.‚Äù

newsArray.title: BCCI invites applications for solitary slot in men‚Äôs selection committee
newsArray.description: Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone.
newsArray.content: The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has invited applications for a solitary position in the senior men‚Äôs national selection committee. Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee led by Ajit Agarkar, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone. According to the notice, the ideal candidate should have played a minimum of seven Test matches or 30 first-class games or 10 ODIs and 20 first-class fixtures. The candidate should also have retired at least five years ago, and no member who has been part of any cricket committee for a total of five years shall be eligible for the role. Interestingly, the notice does not mention any age cap. Though the BCCI had appointed a five-member committee with Chetan Sharma as its chairman in January last year, a sting operation conducted by a television channel forced Sharma to resign from the post. Former India fast bowler Agarkar, who hails from west zone, took charge as the chairman late last year, and now with January 25 as the deadline, it would be interesting to see who applies for the role. Apart from Agarkar and Ankola, Subroto Banerjee, Shiv Sunder Das and S Sharath are the other members of the panel, which surprisingly, does not have a candidate from the north zone. Comments Related Topics

newsArray.title: Grateful Green thought he was Australia‚Äôs next opening batsman
creator: Malcolm Conn
newsArray.description: Cameron Green originally believed he would be a straight swap for David Warner.
newsArray.content: Steve Smith has already begun his new role as an Australian opening batsman, taking the first delivery at training on Monday from new-ball-wielding captain Pat Cummins at the Adelaide Oval. His opening partner Usman Khawaja walked into a net along Smith and faced up to Mitchell Starc, also with a new ball, ahead of the first Test against the West Indies, beginning on Wednesday. Khawaja also slotted into first slip during fielding training, suggesting he will fill the space between wicketkeeper Alex Carey and Steve Smith that was left by David Warner‚Äôs departure. Smith‚Äôs replacement at No.4, Cameron Green, had throw downs in a side net from batting coach Michael Di Venuto, with the recalled allrounder originally believing he was replacing the retiring Warner at the top of the order. ‚ÄúI had no idea until about Wednesday,‚Äù Green said of the decision to bat him at No.4, where he has played with such success for Western Australia, averaging 54. ‚ÄúI was so excited when I heard the news. I thought I was about a 95 per cent chance of opening, so that‚Äôs where my head went for a couple of weeks. Cameron Green at the Adelaide Oval. Credit: Getty ‚ÄúThey [the selectors] didn‚Äôt say anything. I was biding my time, and I was like, well, I might as well get my skills up just in case, and they let me know just to prepare like you normally would. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very excited. I‚Äôve let all the guys know obviously how much I love playing at No.4, and I‚Äôm obviously grateful for the opportunity to be able to do that.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Sealy leads U19s to warm-up win against NZ
newsArray.description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match...
newsArray.content: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match yesterday in South Africa. The Barbadian left-arm spinner bagged four for 21 from nine overs and five other bowlers took one wicket apiece. The Caribbean side dismissed the New Zealanders for 131 in 39.2 overs in the match at the Braam Fisherville Sports Complex. Two of Sealy‚Äôs victims were trapped leg before wicket and another was bowled, to signify the accuracy of his spell, after West Indies won the toss and decided to field. Fellow Barbadian Joshua Dorne, not out on 45, and Antiguan Jewel Andrew, not out on 36, then led the run chase for West Indies. They shared an unbroken stand of 58 for the fifth wicket to get the Caribbean side over the finish line with 25.1 overs remaining, after they stumbled to 74 for four in the 17th over. The match is the first of two for the side, led by Stephan Pascal, ahead of their opening match in the World Cup against hosts South Africa on Friday at the J.B. Marks Oval in Potchefstroom. They face Nepal tomorrow at the St Stithians Main Oval in another warm-up game. West Indies never let New Zealand off the hook, taking wickets at regular intervals throughout the innings, and they reduced the Young Black Caps to 75 for five. Tom Jones led the way with 24 for New Zealand and Lachlan Stackpole got 23, but no other batsmen passed 20. West Indies were 19 for two inside the first five overs. New Zealand pace bowling captain Oscar Jackson took two for 14 from three overs and had them wobbling further before they reached the halfway stage. Dorne, batting at three, held the innings together with some composed batting and carried them the rest of the way in a stable partnership with Andrew. For their first-round matches ‚Äì all to be played at the J.B. Marks Oval ‚Äì West Indies have been drawn alongside the South Africans, Scotland, and England in Group B in the World Cup. They face the Scots on January 24 and the English two days later. The top three sides from each first round group will progress to the Super Six stage to be played from January 30 to February 3. The semi-finals, on February 6 and 8, and the final, on February 11, will all be played at Willowmore Park in Benoni.

newsArray.title: WI hope to rebuild reputation Down Under, says Da Silva
newsArray.description: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five...
newsArray.content: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five players in the 15-member Test squad of the Caribbean side that has returned Down Under for the series that opens on Wednesday at the Adelaide Oval before moving to the Gabba in Brisbane on January 25. West Indies were beaten convincingly in two Tests in late 2022 in Australia, and with several established players making themselves unavailable, including former captain Jason Holder and fellow all-rounder Kyle Mayers, because of Twenty20 franchise playing commitments, the Test squad includes seven uncapped players. At least three of the uncapped players are likely to make their debuts during the first Test, but Da Silva, who requires only two dismissals to reach 100 in the format, said the squad was keen to prove the doubters wrong. ‚ÄúLast year is last year, and we‚Äôre here to try again,‚Äù he told reporters yesterday when West Indies stepped up preparations for the Frank Worrell Trophy series with a training session at the iconic match venue. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to give it our best effort. We have a few new faces, so there‚Äôs going to be a bit of new blood coming in. I know the boys are excited, and I‚Äôm definitely excited and raring to go. ‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs really keen. Seven uncapped players. If they haven‚Äôt gotten a taste, they‚Äôre really raring to go get a taste of it, so the mood in the camp is great, and we‚Äôre really looking forward to it.‚Äù West Indies have not beaten the Australians in a Test series at home or abroad in a little more than 31 years, and they have gone 19 matches in close to 21 years without winning a Test against the Baggy Greens, but Da Silva said the series is a chance for them to start rebuilding their fading Test reputation. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs always the goal,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEach and every one of us here is looking forward to making the West Indies a winning team again. That‚Äôs the main goal we have. ‚ÄúWe talk about it every day, about getting back to those days, but it‚Äôs a new era now, and we‚Äôre just looking forward to making our own brand and playing that brand of cricket.‚Äù Former West Indies captain and batting maestro Brian Lara will spend the two Tests behind the TV commentary microphone for Fox Cricket, but he attended the training session to share some of his knowledge with the players in his role of mentor, which he assumed last February. ‚ÄúThe knowledge he has is second to none,‚Äù Da Silva said about working with his fellow Trinidadian, who holds the world records for highest individual Test and first-class scores of 400 not out and 501 not out, respectively. ‚ÄúWhat he‚Äôs done for the game, what he‚Äôs done for West Indies cricket on his own, just having him around, just his presence alone speaks for itself. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs here to work with everyone, he‚Äôs our mentor, so he‚Äôs going to be helping everybody, bowlers and batters because he has so much experience, I think everybody can learn from him.‚Äù

newsArray.title: BCCI invites applications for solitary slot in men‚Äôs selection committee
newsArray.description: Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone.
newsArray.content: The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has invited applications for a solitary position in the senior men‚Äôs national selection committee. Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee led by Ajit Agarkar, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone. According to the notice, the ideal candidate should have played a minimum of seven Test matches or 30 first-class games or 10 ODIs and 20 first-class fixtures. The candidate should also have retired at least five years ago, and no member who has been part of any cricket committee for a total of five years shall be eligible for the role. Interestingly, the notice does not mention any age cap. Though the BCCI had appointed a five-member committee with Chetan Sharma as its chairman in January last year, a sting operation conducted by a television channel forced Sharma to resign from the post. Former India fast bowler Agarkar, who hails from west zone, took charge as the chairman late last year, and now with January 25 as the deadline, it would be interesting to see who applies for the role. Apart from Agarkar and Ankola, Subroto Banerjee, Shiv Sunder Das and S Sharath are the other members of the panel, which surprisingly, does not have a candidate from the north zone. Comments Related Topics

newsArray.title: Grateful Green thought he was Australia‚Äôs next opening batsman
creator: Malcolm Conn
newsArray.description: Cameron Green originally believed he would be a straight swap for David Warner.
newsArray.content: Steve Smith has already begun his new role as an Australian opening batsman, taking the first delivery at training on Monday from new-ball-wielding captain Pat Cummins at the Adelaide Oval. His opening partner Usman Khawaja walked into a net along Smith and faced up to Mitchell Starc, also with a new ball, ahead of the first Test against the West Indies, beginning on Wednesday. Khawaja also slotted into first slip during fielding training, suggesting he will fill the space between wicketkeeper Alex Carey and Steve Smith that was left by David Warner‚Äôs departure. Smith‚Äôs replacement at No.4, Cameron Green, had throw downs in a side net from batting coach Michael Di Venuto, with the recalled allrounder originally believing he was replacing the retiring Warner at the top of the order. ‚ÄúI had no idea until about Wednesday,‚Äù Green said of the decision to bat him at No.4, where he has played with such success for Western Australia, averaging 54. ‚ÄúI was so excited when I heard the news. I thought I was about a 95 per cent chance of opening, so that‚Äôs where my head went for a couple of weeks. Cameron Green at the Adelaide Oval. Credit: Getty ‚ÄúThey [the selectors] didn‚Äôt say anything. I was biding my time, and I was like, well, I might as well get my skills up just in case, and they let me know just to prepare like you normally would. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very excited. I‚Äôve let all the guys know obviously how much I love playing at No.4, and I‚Äôm obviously grateful for the opportunity to be able to do that.‚Äù

newsArray.title: IND vs. AFG 2nd T20I in Indore: Police detain pitch invader for caressing and hugging Virat Kohli‚Äôs feet
creator: CricketCountry Staff
newsArray.description: A young man was taken into custody after he got past security to hug Virat Kohli during the India vs. Afghanistan T20 International at Holkar Stadium in Indore. The post IND vs. AFG 2nd T20I in Indore: Police detain pitch invader for caressing and hugging Virat Kohli‚Äôs feet appeared first on Cricket Country.
newsArray.content: In the second T20 International, India easily defeated Afghanistan by six wickets, securing a series victory in Indore on Sunday. On a calm pitch at the Holkar Stadium, Afghanistan was bowled out for 172 by Axar Patel, leading the bowling attack. Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shivam Dube then made quick work of half-centuries to help India win with 26 balls remaining. Virat Kohli, the former captain of India, made his T20I cricket debut in this match. Since November 2022, when India faced England in the semi-final of the 2022 T20 World Cup, Kohli has not participated in an international match in the format. while could be expected, the Indore crowd screamed Kohli‚Äôs name a lot during the game, even while he sat in the bench following his dismissal during India‚Äôs chase. During the Afghanistan innings, there was also a minor interruption as a spectator made their way to the ground and collided with Kohli. He hugged Kohli and put his hands on his feet before lifting him off the ground. Police detained the young man and brought him to the Tukoganj police station. According to a police officer, the young person entered the Holkar Stadium through Narendra Hirwani Gate with a match ticket. According to him, the young man appeared to be a huge fan of Kohli and went inside the stadium by scaling the railing of the press box in an attempt to meet the player. The young person was being questioned, the officer said. The official stated that further actions in the matter will be made based on the interrogation. A man in Indore says he was a pitch invader. In the midst of it all, a supporter on the social media site X (previously Twitter) asserted that they were the ones that went past security to give Kohli a hug. The biggest accomplishment of Aarav‚Äôs life, according to him, is having a display photo of Kohli in his profile and using the handle @sigma__male_. During the chase, instead of acting as an anchor like he usually does, Kohli came out running. The 35-year-old scored 29 runs off of 16 balls before getting out in the final powerplay over. Subsequently, Jaiswal and Dube mercilessly battered the bowlers from Afghanistan into submission. Yashasvi was dismissed after smashing 68 off 34 balls, including six sixes, but Dube finished unbeaten with a 32-ball 63 that included four maximums. Jaiswal scored his second consecutive undefeated half-century in this series while hitting six sixes in his innings. The latter, who was undefeated at 60 off 40 balls, had also guided India to victory in the opening game. India‚Äôs chase got off to a rough start as Fazalhaq Farooqi (1-28) knocked out skipper Rohit Sharma for a golden duck. However, Jaiswal, 22, and Virat Kohli, 29, forged a 57-run partnership that put India ahead. When Dube and Jaiswal teamed up for a third-wicket partnership, they quickly put on 92 runs in the next seven overs. When India lost two quick wickets to Karim Janat (2-13), including Jaiswal, the momentum had not changed much.

newsArray.title: Sealy leads U19s to warm-up win against NZ
newsArray.description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match...
newsArray.content: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (CMC): Vice-captain Nathan Sealy led a notable bowling performance, and West Indies Under-19s got a morale-boosting six-wicket win against New Zealand Under-19s in an ICC Men‚Äôs Under-19 Cricket World Cup warm-up match yesterday in South Africa. The Barbadian left-arm spinner bagged four for 21 from nine overs and five other bowlers took one wicket apiece. The Caribbean side dismissed the New Zealanders for 131 in 39.2 overs in the match at the Braam Fisherville Sports Complex. Two of Sealy‚Äôs victims were trapped leg before wicket and another was bowled, to signify the accuracy of his spell, after West Indies won the toss and decided to field. Fellow Barbadian Joshua Dorne, not out on 45, and Antiguan Jewel Andrew, not out on 36, then led the run chase for West Indies. They shared an unbroken stand of 58 for the fifth wicket to get the Caribbean side over the finish line with 25.1 overs remaining, after they stumbled to 74 for four in the 17th over. The match is the first of two for the side, led by Stephan Pascal, ahead of their opening match in the World Cup against hosts South Africa on Friday at the J.B. Marks Oval in Potchefstroom. They face Nepal tomorrow at the St Stithians Main Oval in another warm-up game. West Indies never let New Zealand off the hook, taking wickets at regular intervals throughout the innings, and they reduced the Young Black Caps to 75 for five. Tom Jones led the way with 24 for New Zealand and Lachlan Stackpole got 23, but no other batsmen passed 20. West Indies were 19 for two inside the first five overs. New Zealand pace bowling captain Oscar Jackson took two for 14 from three overs and had them wobbling further before they reached the halfway stage. Dorne, batting at three, held the innings together with some composed batting and carried them the rest of the way in a stable partnership with Andrew. For their first-round matches ‚Äì all to be played at the J.B. Marks Oval ‚Äì West Indies have been drawn alongside the South Africans, Scotland, and England in Group B in the World Cup. They face the Scots on January 24 and the English two days later. The top three sides from each first round group will progress to the Super Six stage to be played from January 30 to February 3. The semi-finals, on February 6 and 8, and the final, on February 11, will all be played at Willowmore Park in Benoni.

newsArray.title: WI hope to rebuild reputation Down Under, says Da Silva
newsArray.description: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five...
newsArray.content: ADELAIDE, Australia (CMC): Wicketkeeper-batsman Joshua Da Silva said West Indies hope to use the two Tests against hosts and world champions Australia to try to restore pride in their tattered brand. The 25-year-old Trinidadian is one of only five players in the 15-member Test squad of the Caribbean side that has returned Down Under for the series that opens on Wednesday at the Adelaide Oval before moving to the Gabba in Brisbane on January 25. West Indies were beaten convincingly in two Tests in late 2022 in Australia, and with several established players making themselves unavailable, including former captain Jason Holder and fellow all-rounder Kyle Mayers, because of Twenty20 franchise playing commitments, the Test squad includes seven uncapped players. At least three of the uncapped players are likely to make their debuts during the first Test, but Da Silva, who requires only two dismissals to reach 100 in the format, said the squad was keen to prove the doubters wrong. ‚ÄúLast year is last year, and we‚Äôre here to try again,‚Äù he told reporters yesterday when West Indies stepped up preparations for the Frank Worrell Trophy series with a training session at the iconic match venue. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to give it our best effort. We have a few new faces, so there‚Äôs going to be a bit of new blood coming in. I know the boys are excited, and I‚Äôm definitely excited and raring to go. ‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs really keen. Seven uncapped players. If they haven‚Äôt gotten a taste, they‚Äôre really raring to go get a taste of it, so the mood in the camp is great, and we‚Äôre really looking forward to it.‚Äù West Indies have not beaten the Australians in a Test series at home or abroad in a little more than 31 years, and they have gone 19 matches in close to 21 years without winning a Test against the Baggy Greens, but Da Silva said the series is a chance for them to start rebuilding their fading Test reputation. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs always the goal,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEach and every one of us here is looking forward to making the West Indies a winning team again. That‚Äôs the main goal we have. ‚ÄúWe talk about it every day, about getting back to those days, but it‚Äôs a new era now, and we‚Äôre just looking forward to making our own brand and playing that brand of cricket.‚Äù Former West Indies captain and batting maestro Brian Lara will spend the two Tests behind the TV commentary microphone for Fox Cricket, but he attended the training session to share some of his knowledge with the players in his role of mentor, which he assumed last February. ‚ÄúThe knowledge he has is second to none,‚Äù Da Silva said about working with his fellow Trinidadian, who holds the world records for highest individual Test and first-class scores of 400 not out and 501 not out, respectively. ‚ÄúWhat he‚Äôs done for the game, what he‚Äôs done for West Indies cricket on his own, just having him around, just his presence alone speaks for itself. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs here to work with everyone, he‚Äôs our mentor, so he‚Äôs going to be helping everybody, bowlers and batters because he has so much experience, I think everybody can learn from him.‚Äù

newsArray.title: BCCI invites applications for solitary slot in men‚Äôs selection committee
newsArray.description: Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone.
newsArray.content: The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has invited applications for a solitary position in the senior men‚Äôs national selection committee. Though the notice put up on the board‚Äôs website does not specify who it would replace from the current five-member committee led by Ajit Agarkar, reports had earlier suggested that the axe could fall on Salil Ankola, since the BCCI does not want two selectors from the west zone. According to the notice, the ideal candidate should have played a minimum of seven Test matches or 30 first-class games or 10 ODIs and 20 first-class fixtures. The candidate should also have retired at least five years ago, and no member who has been part of any cricket committee for a total of five years shall be eligible for the role. Interestingly, the notice does not mention any age cap. Though the BCCI had appointed a five-member committee with Chetan Sharma as its chairman in January last year, a sting operation conducted by a television channel forced Sharma to resign from the post. Former India fast bowler Agarkar, who hails from west zone, took charge as the chairman late last year, and now with January 25 as the deadline, it would be interesting to see who applies for the role. Apart from Agarkar and Ankola, Subroto Banerjee, Shiv Sunder Das and S Sharath are the other members of the panel, which surprisingly, does not have a candidate from the north zone. creator: Malcolm Conn
newsArray.description: Cameron Green originally believed he would be a straight swap for David Warner.
newsArray.content: Steve Smith has already begun his new role as an Australian opening batsman, taking the first delivery at training on Monday from new-ball-wielding captain Pat Cummins at the Adelaide Oval. His opening partner Usman Khawaja walked into a net along Smith and faced up to Mitchell Starc, also with a new ball, ahead of the first Test against the West Indies, beginning on Wednesday. Khawaja also slotted into first slip during fielding training, suggesting he will fill the space between wicketkeeper Alex Carey and Steve Smith that was left by David Warner‚Äôs departure. Smith‚Äôs replacement at No.4, Cameron Green, had throw downs in a side net from batting coach Michael Di Venuto, with the recalled allrounder originally believing he was replacing the retiring Warner at the top of the order. ‚ÄúI had no idea until about Wednesday,‚Äù Green said of the decision to bat him at No.4, where he has played with such success for Western Australia, averaging 54. ‚ÄúI was so excited when I heard the news. I thought I was about a 95 per cent chance of opening, so that‚Äôs where my head went for a couple of weeks. Cameron Green at the Adelaide Oval. Credit: Getty ‚ÄúThey [the selectors] didn‚Äôt say anything. I was biding my time, and I was like, well, I might as well get my skills up just in case, and they let me know just to prepare like you normally would. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very excited. I‚Äôve let all the guys know obviously how much I love playing at No.4, and I‚Äôm obviously grateful for the opportunity to be able to do that.‚Äù
